concept.title: RHEL 7 OS Upgrade and Instance Migrations
concept.shortdesc: This topic describes available scenarios for migrating your cloud instances (VMs) from RHEL 6 to RHEL 7.

p.note: Be sure you have read to understand the interrelated and OS upgrade processes before attempting any of the scenarios described in this section.

conbody.p: There are four possible scenarios for instances (the VMs on the NCs) in your cloud:

row.entry: Instance is moved from a RHEL 6 NC to a RHEL 7 NC without service interruption.
Instance is suspended (packed) on a RHEL 6 NC, moved to a RHEL 7 NC, then resumed (unpacked).
Offline Migration Using a Single NC
Instance is suspended (packed) on a RHEL 6 NC, NC is upgraded to RHEL 7, then resumed (unpacked).
If you have an instance that is test-only, redundant, stale, or otherwise not needed, no need to migrate; simply terminate the instance.

section.title: Live Migration
section.p: In a live migration, is installed on a new (or spare) NC running RHEL 7, and instances are migrated from the old RHEL 6 NC. The migration is managed by KVM.
Benefits of a live migration include:

ul.li: Minimal or no downtime for running instances.
Minimal disruption for cloud users.

section.p: Risks of a live migration include:

ul.li: Live migration is managed by KVM, which may fail. KVM makes no guarantees that any given migration will succeed even when it starts successfully.
Handling large instances with large instance-store-backed storage can take hours or days, resulting in the overall upgrade time for a region taking days or even weeks.
Live migration is very resource intensive; memory, storage, and runtime state must be moved over the network, which might interfere with other workloads.
Live migration requires enough spare capacity to handle migrations/evacuations of NCs.

section.p: For instructions on how to perform a live migration, see .

section.title: Offline Migration Between NCs
section.p: This scenario involves suspending (packing) instances on RHEL 6 NC, dumping their state to disk to create an instance snapshot, moving that data to a RHEL7 NC, and then unpacking the instances to a running state and resuming execution. This approach assumes there is an upgraded RHEL7 NC available for the suspended instance, and preserves the runtime memory state and disk state of the instance to avoid requiring users to reconstruct instances from scratch, but it does require that the instances be down and unavailable for the duration of the pack, dump, copy, unpack, and resume process.
Benefits of an offline migration include:

ul.li: More reliable than a live migration.
Each instance can be moved individually so a given instance's downtime is a function of its size, not the cumulative size of all instances on the source host machine.
Allows a measure of safety, since instances remain on the source NC until they can be confirmed as moved successfully to the destination NC.

section.p: Risks of an offline migration include:

ul.li: Requires instance downtime.
Like a live migration, offline migrations still require the contents of instances to be copied over the network.
Requires additional NCs to receive the suspended instances.
Copying large instances can take a long time.

section.p: For instructions on how to perform this offline migration, see .

section.title: Offline Migration Using a Single NC
section.p: This offline migration scenario is similar to the offline migration between NCs. It assumes that suspended (packed) RHEL 6 instances can be moved off-machine (or using local persistent storage) and then back to the same host before being unpacked on an upgraded RHEL7 NC. This scenario requires sufficient storage to hold packed instances during the upgrade that are not in a location where they can be destroyed or modified by a clean OS install.
Benefits of an offline migration using a single NC include:

ul.li: No network copy of instances required.
No impact on other instances in the cloud because there is no network/resource contention.
No additional capacity is required, since the existing NCs can be used.
Rollback is a clean install of RHEL 6 and if necessary.

section.p: Risks of an offline migration using a single NC include:

ul.li: Complete failure of an NC or accidental wiping of the VM state can result in lost instances.
Requires downtime of all instances at the same time.
Rollback possibilities are not as robust as offline migrations, since the host itself is being upgraded.

section.p: For instructions on how to perform this offline migration, see .
